discussion.content: This shows how screwed up questions are asked by CompTIA
I agree with billie. This question is a joke like the CompTIA cert is. Where does this organization find nitwits to write these questions??

comments.content: Then you probably did not past the test, the question is not regarding Mission Critical, the question is regarding what is mitigated thanks to elasticity.

I'd pick C. I think the two closes answers are C, D toss up. Virtualization can be used to mitigate a lack of redundancy by add new virtual machine to create redundancy. Also, VM Escape attacks, lead to DoS attacks, which leads to data exfiltration. So, I agree with CoRell. 

Benefits, easier and faster to make backups, Malicious code compromises of virtual systems rarely affect the host OS. You would definitely virtualize mission critical systems on a VM to mitigate against DoS attacks. Good luck take your pick.

discussion.content: I'd still pick C. If it's a mission-critical server, you don't want a single point of failure, so lack of redundancy makes more sense to me than DoS.
Billie, you are right. I plan to take the test soon. CompTIA is well respected, what in the world are they doing?
D. Although C (lack of redundancy) would also be mitigated, that lack could result in Denial of Service. So that's the end result that we are mitigating against.

Answer: D
https://www.usenix.org/node/183064

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is deploying a new mission essential server into a virtual environment. Which of the following is BEST mitigated by the environment's rapid elasticity characteristic?
Which of the following is the proper order for logging a user into a system from the first step to the last step?

discussion.content:
Identification: Who are you?
Authentication: Really?
Authorization: OK!

comments.content:
"OK! It's you!" Shouldn't be under authorization. Should be this:

Identification: It's me with "A" username and "B" password
Authentication: Let me check is that really you. OK! It's you!
Authorization: You can only access the files in the "X" directory.

Good dialogue but needs to be improved:
Identification: It's me with "A" username and "B" password
Authentication: Let me check is that really you.
Authorization: OK! It's you! You can only access the files in the "X" directory.

discussion.content: The correct answer is option 'A'. To access a system, the User will have to identify himself by entering personal credential information viz: username and password. These are then authenticated as a way of validation. After this process, the roles and services configured or authorized for the user is then verified in authorization.
finally, a question I can answer with confidence, yay!!

choices.D: Disclosure of sensitive data to third parties due to excessive share permissions
choices.A: Exploitation of local console access and removal of data
choices.C: Remote exfiltration of data using domain credentials
choices.B: Theft of physical hard drives and a breach of confidentiality

discussion.content:
B is not possible because of full disk encryption
C is not possible either because service accounts have the same credentials and level of access as a user account.
D might be possible but only Accounting-pvc has read permissions to the data in the accounting system which is especially meant for them. Removing these permissions would make no sense.

So A, User accounts shouldn't have any file system permissions at all?

comments.content: A also says ‘removal of data’. How do the user remove data I’d the only have read permissions?
Agreed with A - the reason being login on the console is not subject to SHARE permissions. Share permissions are only valid when accessing from network.

discussion.content: Correct Answer: A If somebody was able to logon to the file server locally they would have permissions to read the data.

Answer: A
Explanation:
Users have Read-Only file system permissions, which can be used through physically accessing the server or by remotely accessing the server using SSH or RDP.

If you use share permissions and NTFS files permissions together, the most restrictive permission will take precedence over the other. In order to have access to the files from a share, you need to get access from both of them. Looking at the settings from below, it means that only accounting-svc is meeting both conditions:

File system permissions: Users = Read Only
Share permission: accounting-svc = Read Only

This means that points C & D cannot be applied. As for B, the drive is encrypted, so we can eliminate this answer right away.

So, I say that A is the last one standing. 

My 2 cents.

comments.content:
Everyone has read permissions, so when anyone logs in using their domain credentials, they would all have access to the data. Also, Chegg looks like it has "C" as the answer at the following URL:
https://www.chegg.com/homework-help/questions-and-answers/please-give-choices-correct-incorrect-definitions-choices-abcde-q35285261
I think A is ridiculous and could be true in almost every situation you can imagine. You could always exploit administrator privileges and remove data, but it has nothing to do with the information presented.

discussion.content:
B - not likely since the data are encrypted.
D - the Share permissions are limited to Read by the service account; anything less may mean no file share access.
C - remote exfiltration suggests network access to the file share; the Shared permission being more restrictive overrides the file system permissions, hence domain users can't access the file share.
A - what is left. A domain user or local user can log onto the server via the local console or interactive login, and will have Read access (the Share permission does not apply here). However, Read access cannot delete data, so choice A is ok only if "removal of data" means exfiltration of the data.

comments.content: Could not a remote user do the same? If I was able to remote into the system from home as a credentialed user, what's to prevent me from photographing or Ctrl-A, Ctrl-V an entire document onto my local machine? IMO the answer is (C).

discussion.content: A is the most applicable to this question with the possible answers. The local user can take pictures of the data and do whatever they want with the data.

comments.content:
A = the local user sitting at the computer system accessing the data

C = Remote user accessing data from outside the company network.

discussion.content:
Dunno what A or C mean.. But these potentially are the answers in my mind. 
not sure why A. or why not C.

questions.question_text:
A company stores highly sensitive data files used by the accounting system on a server file share.
The accounting system uses a service account named accounting-svc to access the file share.
The data is protected will a full disk encryption, and the permissions are set as follows:
File system permissions: Users = Read Only
Share permission: accounting-svc = Read Only
Given the listed protections are in place and unchanged, to which of the following risks is the data still subject?

A bank uses a wireless network to transmit credit card purchases to a billing system.
Which of the following would be MOST appropriate to protect credit card information from being accessed by unauthorized individuals outside of the premises?

discussion.content: CompTIA loves Faraday cages

comments.content: We know right. If your torn between the Faraday cage and other choice. Choose Faraday cage. Coz CompTIA loves Faraday cages

discussion.content: Technically 4 answers are wrong !

comments.content: Actually this is a rare case in which the answer is right and very straightforward. Forget what stated in the above comment from Melvin; Faraday cages can be as little as a device, or as big as a room or an entire building; in this case they want to isolate the whole building so that the internal wireless signals cannot be captured from outside (the billing system is obviously inside the bank itself). Faraday cage is an expensive solution (but we are talking of a bank!) but it's definitely the correct answer.

discussion.content:
Answer is Fraday cage because credit card has a chips and uses radio frequency (RFId) to executes any transaction hence Friday cage protect this electromagnetic wave not to transmitting data to wring guys
To answer this problem, a technology called a “Faraday cage” began being added to wallets. The Faraday cage blocks a range of radio frequencies- meaning that the radio waves from the RFID scanning device are blocked by the Faraday cage. Unable to reach the RFID chip in the credit card, no information is transmitted, and your card details remain safely inside your wallet.
Talk about a bunch of crappy choices. Is this Faraday cage the size of a building? Are we assuming the walls are Faraday compliant? I am sure that exists, but damn.

C is the best of the worst answers. We have to assume that the question is asking about protecting the data before it is transmitted wirelessly. The question is vague and poorly stated. It asks Which of the following would be MOST appropriate to protect credit card information from being accessed by unauthorized individuals outside of the premises?” The first sentence says that the bank transmits the credit card purchases via a wireless network. So we assume that they want to protect the credit card information in transit (outside the premises).
Not A. Air gap is a way to isolate computers – not transmitted data – from the internet and/or other networks.
Not B. infrared detection involves cameras to detect heat and motion.
Not C. Faraday cages are devices that enclose, isolate, and protect systems and data – but in this situation the data is in transit, so outside the premises.
Not D. Protected distribution is a wireline or fiber-optics telecommunication system – not wireless.
Not phishing or vhishing because the caller is not trying to gain any information from the callee. He is impersonating as an employee.

'Vishing' is over the phone phishing where scammers will try to persuade people to share information by posing as bank staff or other financial service employees.
Answer is clearly Impersonation.

Answer C.

A. Phishing - Usually done via email and trying to 'phish' to a number of users not one single individual.

B. Shoulder surfing - Looking over a user whist they are on a device to steal information.

C. Impersonation - The question says what type of 'attack' is this - indicating that the user on the phone IS NOT an employee, the user on the phone is 'impersonating' the real employee. I agree it should really be 'vishing' as it is over the phone but this is not a answer option for this specific question.

D. Dumpster diving - Going through garbage to try and find things like credentials, credit card numbers, etc.
How do we know it's impersonation ? There's no proof that he is not an employee. ??
so I assume C is correct as Impersonation is regard as to spoof a real employee......
why no vishing in the answer as it is the correct one....
A or C? Impersonation is defined as something done in person. Vishing is defined as phishing over the phone.

questions.question_text: A help desk technician receives a phone call from an individual claiming to be an employee of the organization and requesting assistance to access a locked account. The help desk technician asks the individual to provide proof of identity before access can be granted. Which of the following types of attack is the caller performing?
